.defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad2)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad3 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [[300, 250], [300, 600], [160, 600]])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad3\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad3',\r\n                        [[300, 250], [160, 600], [300, 600]], 'adBlockMainBodyBottom')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad3)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                var mapping_ad4 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([0,0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad4\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad4',\r\n                        [728, 90], 'adBlockFooter')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad4)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().addEventListener('slotRenderEnded', function (event) {\r\n;                    if (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            if ($(this).find('iframe').length) {\r\n                                $(this).removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/445/1/201/985464\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      <div class=\"wi-date\">24 September 2014</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n        $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article contents</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Todd P. MacKenzie, Douglas Scott, Ian Smail, Edward L. Chapin, Scott C. Chapman, A. Conley, Asantha Cooray, James S. Dunlop, D. Farrah, M. Fich, Andy G. Gibb, Wayne S. Holland, R. J. Ivison, Tim Jenness, Jean-Paul Kneib, Gaelen Marsden, Johan Richard, E. I. Robson, Ivan Valtchanov, Julie L. Wardlow,  Disentangling a group of lensed submm galaxies at <em>z</em>\u223c 2.9, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 445, Issue 1, 21 November 2014, Pages 201\u2013212, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1623\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1623</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f445%2f1%2f201%2f985464\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select                      <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830021 id=\"91830021\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305 is a rich galaxy cluster whose strong lensing is particularly prominent at submm wavelengths. We combine new Submillimetre Common-User Bolometer Array (SCUBA)-2 data with imaging from <em>Herschel</em> Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver (SPIRE) and PACS and <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> in order to try to understand the nature of the sources being lensed. In the region of the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019, we uncover seven multiply imaged galaxies (up from the previously known four), of which six are found to be at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9, and possibly constitute an interacting system. Using a novel forward-modelling approach, we are able to simultaneously deblend and fit spectral energy distributions to the individual galaxies that contribute to the giant submm arc, constraining their dust temperatures, far-infrared luminosities, and star formation rates (SFRs). The submm arc first identified by SCUBA can now be seen to be composed of at least five distinct sources, four of these within a galaxy group at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9. Only a handful of lensed galaxy groups at this redshift are expected on the sky, and thus this is a unique opportunity for studying such systems in detail. The total unlensed luminosity for this galaxy group is (3.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>, which gives an unlensed SFR of (450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a050) M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. This finding suggests that submm source multiplicity, due to physically associated groupings as opposed to chance alignment, extends to fainter flux densities than previously discovered. Many of these systems may also host optical companions undetected in the submm, as is the case here.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: data analysis&quot;\">methods: data analysis</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: interactions&quot;\">galaxies: interactions</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: starburst&quot;\">galaxies: starburst</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;submillimetre: galaxies&quot;\">submillimetre: galaxies</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830023 id=\"91830023\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing has been a useful tool for enabling submm studies. The first results from the Submillimetre Common-User Bolometer Array (SCUBA) submm camera on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT; e.g. Smail, Ivison &amp; Blain\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) used \u2018nature's telescope\u2019 to increase the detection rate of high-redshift submm sources and effectively beat the confusion limit for single-dish studies. Now, <em>Herschel</em> (Pilbratt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) has found that lensing is significant for some of the brightest submm sources, with surveys such as H-ATLAS and HerMES (<em>Herschel</em> Multi-tiered Extragalactic Survey) turning up a population of sources which are boosted enough that they can be studied in great detail in follow-up observations (e.g. Negrello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, the limited resolution of <em>Herschel</em>, and of non-interferometric ground-based observatories such as the JCMT, means that the effects of source blending are a cause of uncertainty in interpreting the results (e.g. Karim et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), made more difficult in practice, since submm-bright sources are known to be typically merging or interacting systems, where disentangling the contribution to the combined spectral energy distribution (SED) is more complicated still. Even worse \u2013 while lensing is nominally achromatic, strong lensing of inhomogeneous extended sources within finite beams is <em>not</em> achromatic, since unresolved regions with different spectral properties can be lensed by different amounts. Thus, the existence of strong lensing can be a double-edged sword, boosting the brightness of some sources, but making the detailed interpretation of their SEDs problematic (Serjeant\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Multiwavelength studies are key to understanding these complex systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305, a massive galaxy cluster at a redshift of 0.55, is lensing several background sources and has been imaged at many different wavelengths: X-ray (Donahue et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), optical (Gioia &amp; Luppino\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Takata et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Kodama et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Moran et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), near-infrared (IR; Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), mid-IR (Geach et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), far-infrared (far-IR; Oliver et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), mm/submm (Chapman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002a</a>; Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and radio (Reese et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Berciano Alba et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In the optical, the previously discovered multiply imaged sources include an extended optical arc composed of a Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) with a spectroscopic redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.911, as well as two extremely red objects (EROs) with a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1, determined from lensing models (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Berciano Alba et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The two EROs and the LBG are so close in separation (\u223c10\u00a0kpc in projection) that they potentially constitute an interacting system. A fourth multiply imaged galaxy was discovered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The steep number counts in the submm make lensing much more striking in this waveband than the optical \u2013 at 850\u00a0\u03bcm, the SCUBA map of the cluster core showed a \u2018giant submm arc\u2019, by far the brightest feature in this region of the sky, with an extent of around 1 arcmin, consistent with the blending of multiple galaxy images which lie near the critical line in the lensing model. If the optical galaxies are indeed interacting, the submm arc could be attributed to triggered star formation within one or more of these galaxies. This scenario is also supported by the radio data, as discussed in Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">New observations, presented here using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>), SCUBA-2 on the JCMT, and PACS and Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver (SPIRE) on <em>Herschel</em>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> shed new light on what is generating the submm arc. With the deeper <em>HST</em> images, and a new <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) lensing model, there are now <em>seven</em> known multiply imaged galaxies (including the previously known four) in the region of the submm arc. Six of these multiply imaged galaxies are consistent with a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 and probably constitute an interacting galaxy group. To properly analyse the submm imaging of SCUBA-2 and <em>Herschel</em>, we have developed a new approach to disentangle the confused components generating the submm arc, which fully exploits the multiply imaged and differentially magnified nature of the system, and allows us to directly estimate both the dust temperature, <em>T</em><sub>d</sub>, and the far-IR luminosity, <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> (and thus star formation rate, SFR), for each of the contributing galaxies. This allows us to investigate the <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> versus <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> relation for intrinsically less luminous galaxies at high-<em>z</em> than traditional blank field surveys. Possible evolution of this relation with redshift allows us to probe the properties of star formation in the early Universe (e.g. Chapman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002b</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Kov\u00e1cs et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Pope et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Chapin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Symeonidis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Sklias et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Our method significantly improves upon the conventional method of extracting sources, or smoothing and binning multiwavelength data to the worst resolution, before fitting SEDs (a process that destroys useful information).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a02, we introduce the <em>HST</em> optical data and the lensing model. In Section\u00a03.1, we present the SCUBA-2 data and in Section\u00a03.2 the <em>Herschel</em> data. In Section\u00a04.1, we present the SED model and image reconstruction methods and in Section\u00a04.2 the model fitting procedure. Section\u00a05.1 discusses the results and Section\u00a06 finishes with the conclusions. Throughout we employ a \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.7$|\u2060</span>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830029 id=\"91830029\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2><em>HST</em> AND THE LENSING MODEL</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the main motivation for our study comes from the new submm data, it makes the most scientific sense to first describe the optical data. We retrieved previously unpublished observations using WFC3 on <em>HST</em> from the Canadian Astronomical Data Centre (programme 11591). The observations were taken at 1.1 and 1.6\u00a0\u03bcm with 2400 and 2600\u00a0s exposures, respectively. A small pointing shift in the data, with respect to <em>HST</em> data published by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), was corrected by aligning to the older <em>HST</em> data in this field. These observations reveal a host of new red objects in the region of the submm arc (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91830031\" scrollto-destination=\"91830031\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=a3vfnAyN~EttAxYwTxya1CLikTpEaNhtbAMax3L-m4A5KOlamzdkntEhO4VEEAy-zgC119E9P~lirhEfSsVG259NYV2dE-dXDKO3SXU-vP~9y8LVVnIeq4o8nIAZ9buxacXkgHMal1i~h9oumlCaWJ2derze3AI5ElNq8u4lZlb~4eKS7Fnr5YNe0OSYq280rq1839IeqGQERwxVSfp2iOSzA85YBSrq5x8NMPlrnag50n~eCEtb6sldrz~bOW9hn8iE1KbAy7sn2ycY8YzAPn-pCg53XdMCEEghBTqmaUFDZsQvkjOuHsL9VpoVHLN1fvNE5Se9XF-6MaaAE0kw4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top-left panel: HST WFC3 colour composite (red: 1.6\u00a0\u03bcm, green: 1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm, blue: 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm), clearly showing the main optical arc (roughly vertical, at about RA$\\,{=}\\,4^\\mathrm{h}54^\\mathrm{m}12{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$), offset slightly from the abundance of red images along the submm arc. The contrast has been stretched to highlight the faint arcs and multiply imaged galaxies. Top-right panel: HST image (1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm) with the positions of the multiply imaged galaxies labelled numerically from 1 through 7, with sub-groups of images labelled as a, b, and c. The galaxy discovered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (2011) is labelled as Galaxy 1 and the two EROs and the LBG discovered by Borys et\u00a0al. (2004) are labelled Galaxy 5, 6, and 7, respectively. The red contour denotes the critical line of the lensing model for a redshift of z\u00a0=\u00a02.911, while the black contours represent the SCUBA-2 850\u00a0\u03bcm emission. Galaxy 8 is a singly imaged source with colours similar to those of the other multiply imaged galaxies, and has been found to be important when trying to reproduce the morphology of the submm arc. Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at a redshift of z\u00a0=\u00a00.157. Bottom: the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019 as seen by Herschel PACS and SPIRE and SCUBA-2 over more than a factor of 5 in wavelength range. The red circles plotted on the shortest and longest wavelength images mark the positions of the galaxies depicted in the top-right panel. It is obvious that this string of multiply imaged z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group sources are responsible for generating the majority of the submm arc. However, they are too spatially confused for traditional deblending techniques.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830031/stu1623fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830031\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=U1e1PP8OWWKhNKaVGCJj4IZoSW5HOAEr6hxxVgXP~Xpc0H-3xinykrSC9vCtlFqjg-HQ~qrdnOyZLUSM8oPhU4ckH3m2v90V1Me90-MXC7PXbg~nzemGA3YlNfFONVfI3C5DpES2-X0fIpj6z3BvyJNFxEuUTn547tMtClG5kUsXJxBHkLR003f8UVVGjRVaxo~-06f2gGgTdX9mcD6wgz3K4HnIAt-OA3wVLImRWhlvqsG~-ysKjLbCiSa1UMxd7kfAoW5T7ihdfesBZaC4wUoRR3UQ~Vs8fq33QtUMZjeSqpaEXnsLa870YjZ0n1vr6KbD81Rx1lkjV5BGYBqgnQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830031&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top-left panel: <em>HST</em> WFC3 colour composite (red: 1.6\u00a0\u03bcm, green: 1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm, blue: 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm), clearly showing the main optical arc (roughly vertical, at about RA<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\,{=}\\,4^\\mathrm{h}54^\\mathrm{m}12{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$|\u2060</span>), offset slightly from the abundance of red images along the submm arc. The contrast has been stretched to highlight the faint arcs and multiply imaged galaxies. Top-right panel: <em>HST</em> image (1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm) with the positions of the multiply imaged galaxies labelled numerically from 1 through 7, with sub-groups of images labelled as <em>a, b,</em> and <em>c</em>. The galaxy discovered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is labelled as Galaxy 1 and the two EROs and the LBG discovered by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) are labelled Galaxy 5, 6, and 7, respectively. The red contour denotes the critical line of the lensing model for a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.911, while the black contours represent the SCUBA-2 850\u00a0\u03bcm emission. Galaxy 8 is a singly imaged source with colours similar to those of the other multiply imaged galaxies, and has been found to be important when trying to reproduce the morphology of the submm arc. Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157. Bottom: the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019 as seen by <em>Herschel</em> PACS and SPIRE and SCUBA-2 over more than a factor of 5 in wavelength range. The red circles plotted on the shortest and longest wavelength images mark the positions of the galaxies depicted in the top-right panel. It is obvious that this string of multiply imaged <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group sources are responsible for generating the majority of the submm arc. However, they are too spatially confused for traditional deblending techniques.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=a3vfnAyN~EttAxYwTxya1CLikTpEaNhtbAMax3L-m4A5KOlamzdkntEhO4VEEAy-zgC119E9P~lirhEfSsVG259NYV2dE-dXDKO3SXU-vP~9y8LVVnIeq4o8nIAZ9buxacXkgHMal1i~h9oumlCaWJ2derze3AI5ElNq8u4lZlb~4eKS7Fnr5YNe0OSYq280rq1839IeqGQERwxVSfp2iOSzA85YBSrq5x8NMPlrnag50n~eCEtb6sldrz~bOW9hn8iE1KbAy7sn2ycY8YzAPn-pCg53XdMCEEghBTqmaUFDZsQvkjOuHsL9VpoVHLN1fvNE5Se9XF-6MaaAE0kw4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top-left panel: HST WFC3 colour composite (red: 1.6\u00a0\u03bcm, green: 1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm, blue: 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm), clearly showing the main optical arc (roughly vertical, at about RA$\\,{=}\\,4^\\mathrm{h}54^\\mathrm{m}12{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$), offset slightly from the abundance of red images along the submm arc. The contrast has been stretched to highlight the faint arcs and multiply imaged galaxies. Top-right panel: HST image (1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm) with the positions of the multiply imaged galaxies labelled numerically from 1 through 7, with sub-groups of images labelled as a, b, and c. The galaxy discovered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (2011) is labelled as Galaxy 1 and the two EROs and the LBG discovered by Borys et\u00a0al. (2004) are labelled Galaxy 5, 6, and 7, respectively. The red contour denotes the critical line of the lensing model for a redshift of z\u00a0=\u00a02.911, while the black contours represent the SCUBA-2 850\u00a0\u03bcm emission. Galaxy 8 is a singly imaged source with colours similar to those of the other multiply imaged galaxies, and has been found to be important when trying to reproduce the morphology of the submm arc. Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at a redshift of z\u00a0=\u00a00.157. Bottom: the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019 as seen by Herschel PACS and SPIRE and SCUBA-2 over more than a factor of 5 in wavelength range. The red circles plotted on the shortest and longest wavelength images mark the positions of the galaxies depicted in the top-right panel. It is obvious that this string of multiply imaged z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group sources are responsible for generating the majority of the submm arc. However, they are too spatially confused for traditional deblending techniques.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830031/stu1623fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830031\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=U1e1PP8OWWKhNKaVGCJj4IZoSW5HOAEr6hxxVgXP~Xpc0H-3xinykrSC9vCtlFqjg-HQ~qrdnOyZLUSM8oPhU4ckH3m2v90V1Me90-MXC7PXbg~nzemGA3YlNfFONVfI3C5DpES2-X0fIpj6z3BvyJNFxEuUTn547tMtClG5kUsXJxBHkLR003f8UVVGjRVaxo~-06f2gGgTdX9mcD6wgz3K4HnIAt-OA3wVLImRWhlvqsG~-ysKjLbCiSa1UMxd7kfAoW5T7ihdfesBZaC4wUoRR3UQ~Vs8fq33QtUMZjeSqpaEXnsLa870YjZ0n1vr6KbD81Rx1lkjV5BGYBqgnQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830031&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top-left panel: <em>HST</em> WFC3 colour composite (red: 1.6\u00a0\u03bcm, green: 1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm, blue: 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm), clearly showing the main optical arc (roughly vertical, at about RA<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\,{=}\\,4^\\mathrm{h}54^\\mathrm{m}12{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$|\u2060</span>), offset slightly from the abundance of red images along the submm arc. The contrast has been stretched to highlight the faint arcs and multiply imaged galaxies. Top-right panel: <em>HST</em> image (1.6 + 1.1\u00a0\u03bcm) with the positions of the multiply imaged galaxies labelled numerically from 1 through 7, with sub-groups of images labelled as <em>a, b,</em> and <em>c</em>. The galaxy discovered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) is labelled as Galaxy 1 and the two EROs and the LBG discovered by Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) are labelled Galaxy 5, 6, and 7, respectively. The red contour denotes the critical line of the lensing model for a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.911, while the black contours represent the SCUBA-2 850\u00a0\u03bcm emission. Galaxy 8 is a singly imaged source with colours similar to those of the other multiply imaged galaxies, and has been found to be important when trying to reproduce the morphology of the submm arc. Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157. Bottom: the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019 as seen by <em>Herschel</em> PACS and SPIRE and SCUBA-2 over more than a factor of 5 in wavelength range. The red circles plotted on the shortest and longest wavelength images mark the positions of the galaxies depicted in the top-right panel. It is obvious that this string of multiply imaged <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group sources are responsible for generating the majority of the submm arc. However, they are too spatially confused for traditional deblending techniques.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and a new lensing model for the cluster, we were able to identify <em>three</em> new multiply imaged galaxies within the <em>HST</em> images in the region of the submm arc. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the positions, amplifications factors, and redshift estimates derived from our model for each of the seven multiply imaged galaxies within the region of the submm arc. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the close positional arrangement of the multiple images with respect to the \u2018giant submm arc\u2019 and the available submm data. Enlarged cut-outs of the multiply imaged galaxies are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) have already suggested that Galaxies 5, 6, and 7 are likely to be an interacting group at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9. Our new model supports their analysis and adds Galaxies 2, 3, and 4 to the same group, expanding it to a group of six galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9. Galaxy 1 is found to have a slightly higher redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03 derived from the lensing model, and thus is not likely associated with the interacting group.</p>                        <a id=\"91830033\" scrollto-destination=\"91830033\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=q~nqKLeEcybvVi8JVxw6wcE6hccDYJ~4DSEmYC-1eojs4dJc5ugkstUoh3mxa178QN6fK7HMy7~gxT5MGOUQP7gvpcngU~Igrm0ZLK9kIMuyZ8SpwoeX3l5EVwfsrv--cNjsPSBJ0boeGzSrw02M-yMo1FxFde0eL65wR0MbZPP3UQ~uyk2x~uTNCzJXAA3srazxesA2eLlEcIwnv1YAOdnZs2wCJlwGRTQBSMROJxf1n2bRcs~tRFADlOaRzult1Z6xwv18EF466DChdZ35KF9D9pjX2dEA1kcifxiEUEZcYwvqjgkoc-R2K3eVAWz4Iec5GSoMc4uBFS6grIPp0g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST cut-outs at the locations of the seven multiply imaged galaxies listed in Table\u00a01 with each column displaying the multiple images of a single galaxy. The letters refer to the three sub-groups of images labelled in Fig.\u00a01. Image 4.b is not shown because it is obscured by foreground galaxies. The letters refer to the three sub-groups of images labelled in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Image 4.b is not shown because it is obscured by foreground galaxies. We show a scale bar for all panels in the lower right.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91830034\" scrollto-destination=\"91830034\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of images for the eight high-<em>z</em> galaxies, as well as one low-redshift interloper at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157. The galaxy IDs denote each galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and the letters indicate the multiple images of each galaxy (with <em>a</em> being the most northern images in each case and <em>c</em> being the most southern images). The position of image 4.b, as inferred from the lensing model, is obscured by foreground cluster galaxies. The amplification factors are derived from the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> modelling in Section\u00a02. The redshift of Galaxy 8 is unknown, but has similar colours to the other high-redshift multiply imaged galaxies, a disturbed morphology, and was found to be important for reproducing the SW extension of the submm arc; thus, we assume a nominal redshift of 2.9. The superscript letters on the redshifts denote the method by which they were derived: <em>a</em> for redshifts derived from the lensing model, <em>b</em> for a spectroscopic redshift, and <em>c</em> for a nominally chosen value. The reported magnitudes are AB magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Gal ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n galaxy\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91830034\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of images for the eight high-<em>z</em> galaxies, as well as one low-redshift interloper at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157. The galaxy IDs denote each galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and the letters indicate the multiple images of each galaxy (with <em>a</em> being the most northern images in each case and <em>c</em> being the most southern images). The position of image 4.b, as inferred from the lensing model, is obscured by foreground cluster galaxies. The amplification factors are derived from the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> modelling in Section\u00a02. The redshift of Galaxy 8 is unknown, but has similar colours to the other high-redshift multiply imaged galaxies, a disturbed morphology, and was found to be important for reproducing the SW extension of the submm arc; thus, we assume a nominal redshift of 2.9. The superscript letters on the redshifts denote the method by which they were derived: <em>a</em> for redshifts derived from the lensing model, <em>b</em> for a spectroscopic redshift, and <em>c</em> for a nominally chosen value. The reported magnitudes are AB magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Gal ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>160<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>110<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Amplification<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Redshift<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>J2000<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>J2000<span
