no-formula-id\">|$\\text{--}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6\u00a0</td><td>31\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>(3.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u00a0</td><td>53\u00a0\u00b1\u00a014\u00a0</td><td>0.31\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.12\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>(7.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>0.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>0.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>0.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>0.16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>0.18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>0.04\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>8\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>(1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td><td>290\u00a0\u00b1\u00a040\u00a0</td><td>2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.4\u00a0</td><td>5.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.8\u00a0</td><td>6.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0\u00a0</td><td>5.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9\u00a0</td><td>5.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0\u00a0</td><td>1.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9\u00a0</td><td><em>17\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09</em>\u00a0</td><td>(1.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>9</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.25\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>3.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0\u00a0</td><td>2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.8\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>0.08\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91830065\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows a degeneracy between the luminosity of Galaxy 6 versus Galaxy 5 in our model, due to their close proximity. While our model prefers emission from Galaxy 6, Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) found that Galaxy 5 has associated radio emission, and hence we might consider that the submm emission attributed to Galaxy 6 in our model actually originates from Galaxy 5. We can test this hypothesis using the far-IR-to-radio correlation to predict a luminosity for Galaxy 5 and by also removing Galaxy 6 from our model and performing the fitting procedure again (thus, forcing our model to attribute a portion of its luminosity to Galaxy 5), and then comparing the results. When doing so, we find that Galaxy 5 is attributed a luminosity of (4.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub> by our model (i.e. essentially all the luminosity of Galaxies 5 and 6 together). Using the peak flux density measurements of Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) at 1.4\u00a0GHz and the amplification factors in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, the unlensed 1.4\u00a0GHz flux density for Galaxy 5 is (11 \u00b1 1)\u2009\u03bcJy. With these two measurements, we can calculate the logarithmic ratio of the far-IR flux to radio flux density, <em>q</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0log<sub>10</sub>[(<em>S</em><sub>IR</sub>/3.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009W\u2009m<sup>\u22122</sup>)/(<em>S</em><sub>1.4</sub>/W\u2009m<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009Hz<sup>\u22121</sup>)]. We assume a power law for the radio SED, <em>S</em><sub>radio</sub>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bd<sup>\u03b1</sup>, with \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0\u22120.8, and we <em>K</em>-correct for redshift. We find <em>q</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.67\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09, which is 2\u03c3 below the relation found by Ivison et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>) for high-<em>z</em> galaxies, <em>q</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3. This indicates that Galaxy 5 may have excess radio emission, suggesting contribution from an AGN, rather than radio emission associated with star formation. For this reason, we tend to follow the results which come from our model fitting, i.e. that Galaxy 6 dominates the far-IR emission. Nevertheless, it remains the case that interpretation of this pair is difficult with existing data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) to obtain high-resolution imaging, Hodge et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) recently showed that many of the SMGs previously detected in the LABOCA ECDFS Submillimeter Survey (LESS) are in fact composed of multiple fainter sources. The group of galaxies behind MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305, consisting of Galaxies 2 through 8, is another good example of SMGs being composed of several sources. Unlensed, this <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group would appear as a point source to any of the current single-dish submm telescopes, with flux densities of 3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5, 8.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9, 10.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1, 8.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.9, 8.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0, and 2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0mJy at 160, 250, 350, 500, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively. This would put the group below the LESS survey detection threshold of 4.5\u00a0mJy at 870\u00a0\u03bcm; hence, we are seeing evidence of submm source multiplicity due to physically associated groupings, as opposed to chance alignment, extending to fainter flux densities. On account of the frequency of submm source multiplicity, Hodge et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) suggest that many are likely to be physically associated. Our findings support this claim and suggest that these systems could be part of larger groups, many of which are too faint to be detected in the submm at current depths. The coincidence of being highly magnified by a massive foreground cluster allows us to study this group in much greater detail than would otherwise be possible, but we cannot infer how rare such SMG groups might be.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although not as striking, a few analogues of our lensed star-forming galaxy group are found in the literature. First of all SMM J09431+4700, a SCUBA-selected hyperluminous IR galaxy behind A851 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.35 (Cowie, Barger &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Ledlow et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). It is accompanied by an optically selected galaxy, DG 433 (Trager et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), separated by 400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in redshift and 1\u00a0Mpc in projection. Secondly, there is SMM J16359+6612, a faint SCUBA-selected galaxy behind A2218 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.5165 (Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Sheth et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). It is accompanied by two optically selected galaxies, separated by only 100\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in redshift and 130\u00a0kpc in projection. With more unlensed analogues of groups and recent mergers in the literature (e.g. Frayer et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Borne et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and the ALMA multiplicity results from Hodge et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), it is clear that mergers and interactions play an important role for many SMGs. These distant galaxy groups are akin to nearby compact groups (Hickson\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1982</a>), with the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group presented here reminiscent perhaps to Stephan's Quintet (Stephan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1877</a>), due to the remarkable number of galaxies associated with this submm source. There are surely more such systems to be discovered.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we believe that situations like we found here are fairly rare, and it is possible that what we have described in this paper is the largest compact group that is lensed by a rich galaxy cluster on the entire sky. Although a detailed estimate of the probability is clouded by the usual problems with a posteriori statistics (i.e. if we only consider systems exactly like we found, then the probability would be arbitrarily small), we can carry out a crude estimate as follows. The MS0451 cluster has a mass of around 10<sup>15</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Donahue et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and an Einstein radius of around 30\u00a0arcsec. Conservatively taking 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> as the limit for rich clusters, surveys (like the Planck catalogue of Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich sources; Planck Collaboration XXIX\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) suggest that there are around 2000 such clusters on the sky, and hence the sum of the areas covered by their Einstein radii (where strong lensing is possible) is about 10<sup>\u22125</sup> of the sky. Assuming that a compact group has a mass of at least 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, then the Press\u2013Schechter formalism (Press &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1974</a>) suggests a comoving density of about 10<sup>\u22126</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22123</sup> at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03 for such groups. Taking a volume that covers \u0394<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 centred on <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03, we estimate 500\u00a0000 such groups on the sky. Finally, multiplying this by the fraction of the sky that might be strongly lensed by rich clusters, we find that there will only be a handful of high-redshift compact groups lensed by a rich cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830070 id=\"91830070\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>Physical properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SED fits within our model allow us to investigate the physical conditions of each component of the submm arc. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> plots <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> versus <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> for the four <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxies constrained by our model with trends and data found by Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and Smail et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). As described in Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), studying the relation between these two quantities gives insight into the nature of star formation within galaxies: a flat relation with <em>T</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0constant implies that star formation regions become more extended when increasing far-IR luminosity, while something close to the Stefan\u2013Boltzmann law, <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>T</em><sup>4</sup>, would imply constant star formation region size (for optically thick star-forming clouds). Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) used <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE and PACS to probe this relation and found the trend plotted as a solid black line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, with dashed lines showing the dispersion. When comparing low- and high-redshift galaxies, they found that the latter were up to 10\u00a0K cooler than their low-redshift counterparts, suggesting evolution with redshift towards more extended star-forming regions in the early universe. Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) found a similar trend with high-redshift galaxies being on average 2\u20133\u00a0K colder than low-redshift galaxies. Smail et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) found that stacking on narrow-band [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters and MIPS+radio sources within a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.6 cluster (intrinsically faint sources) found no evidence of evolution, although their direct detections with SPIRE and SCUBA-2 (thus intrinsically luminous sources) were also found to be cooler in temperature. A recent study by Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) used gravitational lensing to examine intrinsically fainter galaxies at high redshifts. Although limited by small number statistics, they found the opposite trend for high-redshift galaxies. When adding the four <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxies constrained by our model, our results appear to support those found by Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This suggests that selection effects and/or biases are present in the different studies.</p>                        <a id=\"91830072\" scrollto-destination=\"91830072\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=wIwc2MSwlEUHjTEOo9tfVQOx9qsVbyOzFmoMwLQAzCQVefbnkBqY2-4A8GVD3bGJ1xqfiUrnhnmI5l9EOYXxrTUh0CdFhyH7Ugh3Z5peQbJztJIpfw4QdVH4m1DsESl8nu3tWqT4P7mVBUGLCbIr2~P9PnSCGix8HeJFL9l9aDj2dYk-caV~J8fS2rrku7hO1Ia~u4j24qBssrteGvebklUbjVrf-X2~QvUDtjt0Mc3w4Ho5-0YOkny-EXOF-0Ih1Hzv8Ly-SHx~2nUKQUyCMkhv30Rv6lD3BzlUrT-Io8jWlF0oIYV4wV1JyJrL87A82FYcirkJ3hO4prpvnSe-NA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dust temperature versus far-IR luminosity for several samples of galaxies. The solid line shows the trend found by Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (2013) using Herschel for z\u00a0\u223c\u00a00\u20131.5 galaxies, with the dashed lines showing the dispersion of the sample. The green squares are the LESS SMGs followed up by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2014) with ALMA and Herschel, with z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20136. The blue squares are the results of stacking on narrow-band [O\u2009ii] emitters (left) and MIPS+radio sources not detected in SPIRE/SCUBA-2 (right) for a z\u00a0=\u00a01.6 cluster (Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a02014). The red squares are a sample of lensed SMGs discovered with Herschel (Sklias et\u00a0al.\u00a02014) with z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133. The black circles are the four z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies that compose the submm arc of MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305. Both Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2014) and Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (2013) found that high-z galaxies are on average cooler than the z\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, while Sklias et\u00a0al. (2014) and our results report warmer than average results for high-z galaxies. The dotted red line represents the SPIRE 250\u00a0\u03bcm detection limit as a function of dust temperature for z\u00a0=\u00a02.9 galaxies, illustrating the usefulness of gravitational lensing, to push to fainter objects, when studying high-z SMGs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830072/stu1623fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830072\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=FAGT5EVtHC8qirkYn3ZaMIAJ8ZlNMoYzehauF~svbOPEAShcyM~3dUdlnVLpa-XQvqNzFsLmPEZ-Fw8sNJ8uRvrDbh3z67czcN6-~hl~sHh78U17heqOldYQxgxeLHLSZU1BzowQx8YpYz4Qwesm4h5mcskM8MXiyxFeYc3dKezlvsA2iOEpaOjJUvGlEWTXPnAmGUUTAYi5Eq5Iu5M7Te8tEW~kpR8yod1nM4PWq37Upan~13Ba-ronmrdWKlnYQvolpydZzx-GdZTx~9zgz81IU5DPkLiggALErjrxuKCw-qbRh6VLVSrsHnIb8PXXIka7UipxPFY350WzWfzv-g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830072&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dust temperature versus far-IR luminosity for several samples of galaxies. The solid line shows the trend found by Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) using <em>Herschel</em> for <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00\u20131.5 galaxies, with the dashed lines showing the dispersion of the sample. The green squares are the LESS SMGs followed up by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) with ALMA and <em>Herschel</em>, with <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20136. The blue squares are the results of stacking on narrow-band [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters (left) and MIPS+radio sources not detected in SPIRE/SCUBA-2 (right) for a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.6 cluster (Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The red squares are a sample of lensed SMGs discovered with <em>Herschel</em> (Sklias et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) with <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133. The black circles are the four <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies that compose the submm arc of MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305. Both Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) found that high-<em>z</em> galaxies are on average cooler than the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, while Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and our results report warmer than average results for high-<em>z</em> galaxies. The dotted red line represents the SPIRE 250\u00a0\u03bcm detection limit as a function of dust temperature for <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.9 galaxies, illustrating the usefulness of gravitational lensing, to push to fainter objects, when studying high-<em>z</em> SMGs.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=wIwc2MSwlEUHjTEOo9tfVQOx9qsVbyOzFmoMwLQAzCQVefbnkBqY2-4A8GVD3bGJ1xqfiUrnhnmI5l9EOYXxrTUh0CdFhyH7Ugh3Z5peQbJztJIpfw4QdVH4m1DsESl8nu3tWqT4P7mVBUGLCbIr2~P9PnSCGix8HeJFL9l9aDj2dYk-caV~J8fS2rrku7hO1Ia~u4j24qBssrteGvebklUbjVrf-X2~QvUDtjt0Mc3w4Ho5-0YOkny-EXOF-0Ih1Hzv8Ly-SHx~2nUKQUyCMkhv30Rv6lD3BzlUrT-Io8jWlF0oIYV4wV1JyJrL87A82FYcirkJ3hO4prpvnSe-NA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dust temperature versus far-IR luminosity for several samples of galaxies. The solid line shows the trend found by Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (2013) using Herschel for z\u00a0\u223c\u00a00\u20131.5 galaxies, with the dashed lines showing the dispersion of the sample. The green squares are the LESS SMGs followed up by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2014) with ALMA and Herschel, with z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20136. The blue squares are the results of stacking on narrow-band [O\u2009ii] emitters (left) and MIPS+radio sources not detected in SPIRE/SCUBA-2 (right) for a z\u00a0=\u00a01.6 cluster (Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a02014). The red squares are a sample of lensed SMGs discovered with Herschel (Sklias et\u00a0al.\u00a02014) with z\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133. The black circles are the four z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies that compose the submm arc of MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305. Both Swinbank et\u00a0al. (2014) and Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (2013) found that high-z galaxies are on average cooler than the z\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, while Sklias et\u00a0al. (2014) and our results report warmer than average results for high-z galaxies. The dotted red line represents the SPIRE 250\u00a0\u03bcm detection limit as a function of dust temperature for z\u00a0=\u00a02.9 galaxies, illustrating the usefulness of gravitational lensing, to push to fainter objects, when studying high-z SMGs.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830072/stu1623fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830072\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=FAGT5EVtHC8qirkYn3ZaMIAJ8ZlNMoYzehauF~svbOPEAShcyM~3dUdlnVLpa-XQvqNzFsLmPEZ-Fw8sNJ8uRvrDbh3z67czcN6-~hl~sHh78U17heqOldYQxgxeLHLSZU1BzowQx8YpYz4Qwesm4h5mcskM8MXiyxFeYc3dKezlvsA2iOEpaOjJUvGlEWTXPnAmGUUTAYi5Eq5Iu5M7Te8tEW~kpR8yod1nM4PWq37Upan~13Ba-ronmrdWKlnYQvolpydZzx-GdZTx~9zgz81IU5DPkLiggALErjrxuKCw-qbRh6VLVSrsHnIb8PXXIka7UipxPFY350WzWfzv-g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830072&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dust temperature versus far-IR luminosity for several samples of galaxies. The solid line shows the trend found by Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) using <em>Herschel</em> for <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00\u20131.5 galaxies, with the dashed lines showing the dispersion of the sample. The green squares are the LESS SMGs followed up by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) with ALMA and <em>Herschel</em>, with <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01\u20136. The blue squares are the results of stacking on narrow-band [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitters (left) and MIPS+radio sources not detected in SPIRE/SCUBA-2 (right) for a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.6 cluster (Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The red squares are a sample of lensed SMGs discovered with <em>Herschel</em> (Sklias et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) with <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133. The black circles are the four <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies that compose the submm arc of MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305. Both Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Symeonidis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) found that high-<em>z</em> galaxies are on average cooler than the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 relation, while Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and our results report warmer than average results for high-<em>z</em> galaxies. The dotted red line represents the SPIRE 250\u00a0\u03bcm detection limit as a function of dust temperature for <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.9 galaxies, illustrating the usefulness of gravitational lensing, to push to fainter objects, when studying high-<em>z</em> SMGs.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As has been pointed out before (e.g. Chapman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Chapin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), selection effects can be extremely important when studying the correlation between <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>. The Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) sample of SMGs were selected at 870\u00a0\u03bcm, and thus may be biased towards lower dust temperatures, and those of Sklias et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) were formally selected at 160\u00a0\u03bcm, and thus could be biased towards warmer dust temperatures. It should be noted that the submm arc in MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305 was first discovered at 850\u00a0\u03bcm (Chapman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002a</a>), and therefore is unlikely to be biased towards the warmer dust temperatures that we find.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the selection biases inherent in focusing on a single distinctive source, there are also a number of systematic uncertainties that could be present in our modelling approach. Most importantly, we have fixed the amplification factors for the galaxy images. Any errors in amplification can affect our results in several ways. For example, since the contributions to the submm arc from Galaxies 7 and 8 (See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) are mostly point-like, any uncertainty in amplification predominantly affects their measured far-IR luminosities and SFRs. This is especially true for Galaxy 7, because two of its images lie very close to the critical line, and thus its amplification is highly sensitive to any offset between optical and submm components of the galaxy. The uncertainty in relative amplification between galaxy images likely affects which galaxies are preferred by the data. For example, the images of Galaxies 5 and 6 are spatially very close; thus, the different relative amplifications between their respective images probably contribute to Galaxy 6 being preferred by the model fits.</p>                        <a id=\"91830075\" scrollto-destination=\"91830075\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=1ydQ0aH~KU1cQk6ga-s8NYIMbkDAOosYGZjSCjsW-gu8btGP9625tMfRG~QURplVIzT6sdfx9QqxrGxtuogFa4GZAfsTFwxN68qak34Y9Xf5qJpuRKrjt35NxdE7PJ4UqomMVe5WxXj7RqcmY0AeozejGGaoUX5flw~vcriv3NdMOMgbJOSsXFzf3BytUQFPhYlEK-BQrB7xsn9Qcc0YrlhGzuR~jcG9j7VyjrVEJdxtUtH9tbjqo3~3rqEUqAtoccsLhDBf1OsnZ-k4SZs9Z2Q~vMaJqtWC6z8FFAIWj3FYRIgX-Nz6gw61DawoLjP5UaKnifhlFBrj54HAkvI4aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Decomposition of the submm arc into each contributing galaxy for the best-fitting model, the total emission for the best-fitting model, the data, and the residual after subtracting the model from the data. The columns display the contributions for individual galaxies across the six wavelength channels. Due to the differential amplification and unique positions of the multiple images, the emission from each galaxy is morphologically unique and this is what enables us to disentangle their contributions. The data and residual components for the SCUBA-2 channels have been smoothed with the FWHM for each respective wavelength. The pixel sizes are 3, 6, 8.3, 12, 2, and 4 arcsec at 160, 250, 350, 500, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830075/stu1623fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830075\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=inCAXMRwGBBzMkOIIUsybzGc4kwZWAg-avweWnfZWNh-tbsDpjwkIburKeQqXNnSjg2U1nr3pqUO2aCwu4VoE6GrzdC~b5JLQi5LOlEG6Q1R82hbtTIqLr9s6hVEp3T3AomZ57ivEmUMs4pPB~HwGW18~lLVfhWTSyt2DenWF-wGtSuKOeao39nvQsZi-EQd2lXT72yfTzUnv7Z1fEnq4B~soTY5ntwrqBC7kasrHtEl3S94cNZMKAXUNZ7xwwnZogs7cEJRweVrBzDi3bJpMWPG1o-V8U8CplSqPbFP~b5lMIntI5CnEAfxcIpGzIhdj165X3ctNVi8dtyHtYKjBw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830075&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Decomposition of the submm arc into each contributing galaxy for the best-fitting model, the total emission for the best-fitting model, the data, and the residual after subtracting the model from the data. The columns display the contributions for individual galaxies across the six wavelength channels. Due to the differential amplification and unique positions of the multiple images, the emission from each galaxy is morphologically unique and this is what enables us to disentangle their contributions. The data and residual components for the SCUBA-2 channels have been smoothed with the FWHM for each respective wavelength. The pixel sizes are 3, 6, 8.3, 12, 2, and 4 arcsec at 160, 250, 350, 500, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=1ydQ0aH~KU1cQk6ga-s8NYIMbkDAOosYGZjSCjsW-gu8btGP9625tMfRG~QURplVIzT6sdfx9QqxrGxtuogFa4GZAfsTFwxN68qak34Y9Xf5qJpuRKrjt35NxdE7PJ4UqomMVe5WxXj7RqcmY0AeozejGGaoUX5flw~vcriv3NdMOMgbJOSsXFzf3BytUQFPhYlEK-BQrB7xsn9Qcc0YrlhGzuR~jcG9j7VyjrVEJdxtUtH9tbjqo3~3rqEUqAtoccsLhDBf1OsnZ-k4SZs9Z2Q~vMaJqtWC6z8FFAIWj3FYRIgX-Nz6gw61DawoLjP5UaKnifhlFBrj54HAkvI4aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Decomposition of the submm arc into each contributing galaxy for the best-fitting model, the total emission for the best-fitting model, the data, and the residual after subtracting the model from the data. The pixel sizes are 3, 6, 8.3, 12, 2, and 4 arcsec at 160, 250, 350, 500, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830075/stu1623fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830075\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=inCAXMRwGBBzMkOIIUsybzGc4kwZWAg-avweWnfZWNh-tbsDpjwkIburKeQqXNnSjg2U1nr3pqUO2aCwu4VoE6GrzdC~b5JLQi5LOlEG6Q1R82hbtTIqLr9s6hVEp3T3AomZ57ivEmUMs4pPB~HwGW18~lLVfhWTSyt2DenWF-wGtSuKOeao39nvQsZi-EQd2lXT72yfTzUnv7Z1fEnq4B~soTY5ntwrqBC7kasrHtEl3S94cNZMKAXUNZ7xwwnZogs7cEJRweVrBzDi3bJpMWPG1o-V8U8CplSqPbFP~b5lMIntI5CnEAfxcIpGzIhdj165X3ctNVi8dtyHtYKjBw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830075&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Decomposition of the submm arc into each contributing galaxy for the best-fitting model, the total emission for the best-fitting model, the data, and the residual after subtracting the model from the data. The columns display the contributions for individual galaxies across the six wavelength channels. Due to the differential amplification and unique positions of the multiple images, the emission from each galaxy is morphologically unique and this is what enables us to disentangle their contributions. The data and residual components for the SCUBA-2 channels have been smoothed with the FWHM for each respective wavelength. The pixel sizes are 3, 6, 8.3, 12, 2, and 4 arcsec at 160, 250, 350, 500, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91830076\" scrollto-destination=\"91830076\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=gLgAE2E~sCci37MlPeowPTLFTK6sDAV-pmopq7T2BkJsQeVCeGZ1qlZ73l1wdJa-g91WyyjbjsdROyKKMelrxABiV~3dFJlI6b5ZiGFz5tKnX9sBlKw65hm5CWVdwLbQ9Znwmi6svGfRmxYoTinN5DRNmdwi~9oxHE~ynYeFO3TwD9vrWwgWqEjBdYj0kUH9FEaI1JPvY119In8uCLrE-4XEbyp6Hjn~SS~nwRDdBZLWkGgo1WsUmLpRxO3liuOEvxkyBzM1tfpBaBid30iMLytFPMnvmWGh6USy~euu2gB95BdK~PXLTsFAmmYBO2FCZ-o3X2N4R0u-9p4Pe66Ebw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MCMC likelihood contours for temperature and far-IR luminosity for the galaxies that were found to contribute to the submm arc. The contour levels are 68, 95, and 99.7\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence intervals. Because of the morphological uniqueness of the lensing for each individual galaxy, there are few degeneracies here, despite the images of the system being spatially confused. The most obvious degeneracy is between the far-IR luminosity of Galaxies 6 and 7. Top-right panel: the likelihood contours for the model show a degeneracy between Galaxies 5 and 6 in far-IR luminosity. Galaxy 5 has associated radio emission, but it exceeds that expected from SFR alone, thus suggesting an AGN component.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830076/stu1623fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830076\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=jrc4ij4R6iDC4dzm~alqnOQrr2VWOQaqb8ighHI5zZvDbCQCmbX5xESHGeY4DzEgeIjVDULCuKYGOxVj6MRqZMmVlClNHI7q2czKDSvV7zlcXXat2-7R3UcVQeHT95BIw9QK~EkwIwe-2w2Tpm2w65F9vjlkOylXvK12fPSY1CjOO0BPaChlqJpQ8M0lVcQHgBSxCfLhLPswTrzI1RhO66-aUR9gvyHJ5ggvTdJtVZtTW3dlE-PIqT9ZnIYaKK5cb8BZvBcfPOWbGVwpOe2EuQQncxF4Aww24ekXqNBiV2BCDL3a1mHDMoWy17vVBsojj7jY7KiKE0Oq7f4zXJYuQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830076&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">MCMC likelihood contours for temperature and far-IR luminosity for the galaxies that were found to contribute to the submm arc. The contour levels are 68, 95, and 99.7\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence intervals. Because of the morphological uniqueness of the lensing for each individual galaxy, there are few degeneracies here, despite the images of the system being spatially confused. The most obvious degeneracy is between the far-IR luminosity of Galaxies 6 and 7. Top-right panel: the likelihood contours for the model show a degeneracy between Galaxies 5 and 6 in far-IR luminosity. Galaxy 5 has associated radio emission, but it exceeds that expected from SFR alone, thus suggesting an AGN component.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=gLgAE2E~sCci37MlPeowPTLFTK6sDAV-pmopq7T2BkJsQeVCeGZ1qlZ73l1wdJa-g91WyyjbjsdROyKKMelrxABiV~3dFJlI6b5ZiGFz5tKnX9sBlKw65hm5CWVdwLbQ9Znwmi6svGfRmxYoTinN5DRNmdwi~9oxHE~ynYeFO3TwD9vrWwgWqEjBdYj0kUH9FEaI1JPvY119In8uCLrE-4XEbyp6Hjn~SS~nwRDdBZLWkGgo1WsUmLpRxO3liuOEvxkyBzM1tfpBaBid30iMLytFPMnvmWGh6USy~euu2gB95BdK~PXLTsFAmmYBO2FCZ-o3X2N4R0u-9p4Pe66Ebw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"MCMC likelihood contours for temperature and far-IR luminosity for the galaxies that were found to contribute to the submm arc. The contour levels are 68, 95, and 99.7\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence intervals. Because of the morphological uniqueness of the lensing for each individual galaxy, there are few degeneracies here, despite the images of the system being spatially confused. The most obvious degeneracy is between the far-IR luminosity of Galaxies 6 and 7. Top-right panel: the likelihood contours for the model show a degeneracy between Galaxies 5 and 6 in far-IR luminosity. Galaxy 5 has associated radio emission, but it exceeds that expected from SFR alone, thus suggesting an AGN component.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830076/stu1623fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830076\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=jrc4ij4R6iDC4dzm~alqnOQrr2VWOQaqb8ighHI5zZvDbCQCmbX5xESHGeY4DzEgeIjVDULCuKYGOxVj6MRqZMmVlClNHI7q2czKDSvV7zlcXXat2-7R3UcVQeHT95BIw9QK~EkwIwe-2w2Tpm2w65F9vjlkOylXvK12fPSY1CjOO0BPaChlqJpQ8M0lVcQHgBSxCfLhLPswTrzI1RhO66-aUR9gvyHJ5ggvTdJtVZtTW3dlE-PIqT9ZnIYaKK5cb8BZvBcfPOWbGVwpOe2EuQQncxF4Aww24ekXqNBiV2BCDL3a1mHDMoWy17vVBsojj7jY7KiKE0Oq7f4zXJYuQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830076&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">MCMC likelihood contours for temperature and far-IR luminosity for the galaxies that were found to contribute to the submm arc. The contour levels are 68, 95, and 99.7\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence intervals. Because of the morphological uniqueness of the lensing for each individual galaxy, there are few degeneracies here, despite the images of the system being spatially confused. The most obvious degeneracy is between the far-IR luminosity of Galaxies 6 and 7. Top-right panel: the likelihood contours for the model show a degeneracy between Galaxies 5 and 6 in far-IR luminosity. Galaxy 5 has associated radio emission, but it exceeds that expected from SFR alone, thus suggesting an AGN component.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is possible that the simple SED model we have adopted may not accurately approximate the true SEDs of the galaxies in the lensed system. The dust emissivity, \u03b2, is known to be partially degenerate with dust temperature and we have fixed it to a nominal value of 1.5; thus, the uncertainties reported for dust temperatures are likely too small. Furthermore, although these newer <em>HST</em> data are both deeper and at a longer wavelength, it is possible that we are missing fainter group members, as was the case in previous studies (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Berciano Alba et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). If any of the galaxies are not at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9, their reported far-IR luminosities and thus SFRs will be affected, since the distances to the galaxies are used in these calculations. This is especially true for Galaxy 8, as we have no constraints on its actual redshift and our analysis has assumed it to be part of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite these reservations, the model we have adopted appears to provide a reasonably good fit to the data across a wide range of wavelengths. Higher resolution submm data would be needed to further investigate the nature of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830079 id=\"91830079\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">With our new modelling approach, we have overcome the confused nature of this complex system by fully exploiting the differential amplification across the galaxy group and the multiple imaging caused by the strong gravitational lensing. This has allowed us to tackle the challenge of disentangling and fitting SEDs to multiple components of the submm arc. We have shown that the submm arc is predominantly generated by four of the seven galaxies that probably comprise a group at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9, with star formation likely triggered by the galaxies undergoing a merger. It is therefore not necessary to have a hidden region of dust-enshrouded star formation (as postulated by Berciano Alba et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to explain the morphology of the submm arc. This method also demonstrates the power of a broad multiwavelength approach to fully understanding the nature of the submm arc: <em>HST</em> imaging gives us the priors on galaxy positions, as well as providing the constraints for the lensing model; <em>Herschel</em> samples the peak of the far-IR SED, as well as providing the high-resolution far-IR imaging at 160\u00a0\u03bcm; and SCUBA-2 850\u00a0\u03bcm data sample the long-wavelength portion of the FIR SED at a resolution that closely matches that of the 160\u00a0\u03bcm imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This is a unique system that gives us a glimpse into the formation of structure and stars in the early Universe, and no other submm lens discovered to date can match the number of separate galaxies lensed from the same redshift. Spectroscopy and high-resolution follow-up with new interferometer observatories will be the key to confirming and unravelling the nature of this high-<em>z</em> merging galaxy group.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research has been supported by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada. IRS acknowledges support from STFC (ST/I001573/1), a Leverhulme Fellowship, the ERC Advanced Investigator programme DUSTYGAL, and a Royal Society/Wolfson merit award. The James Clerk Maxwell Telescope is operated by the Joint Astronomy Centre on behalf of the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the National Research Council of Canada, and (until 2013 March 31) the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research. Additional funds for the construction of SCUBA-2 were provided by the Canada Foundation for Innovation. SPIRE has been developed by a consortium of institutes led by Cardiff University (UK) and including University of Lethbridge (Canada); NAOC (China); CEA, LAM (France); IFSI, University of Padua (Italy); IAC (Spain); Stockholm Observatory (Sweden); Imperial College London, RAL, UCL-MSSL, UKATC, University of Sussex (UK); and Caltech, JPL, NHSC, University of Colorado (USA). This development has been supported by national funding agencies: CSA (Canada); NAOC (China); CEA, CNES, CNRS (France); ASI (Italy); MCINN (Spain); SNSB (Sweden); STFC, UKSA (UK); and NASA (USA). PACS has been developed by a consortium of institutes led by MPE (Germany) and including UVIE (Austria); KU Leuven, CSL, IMEC (Belgium); CEA, LAM (France); MPIA (Germany); INAF-IFSI/OAA/OAP/OAT, LENS, SISSA (Italy); IAC (Spain). This development has been supported by the funding agencies BMVIT (Austria), ESA-PRODEX (Belgium), CEA/CNES (France), DLR (Germany), ASI/INAF (Italy), and CICYT/MCYT (Spain). This research has made use of data from the HerMES project (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://hermes.sussex.ac.uk/\" target=\"_blank\">http://hermes.sussex.ac.uk/</a>), a Herschel Key Programme utilizing Guaranteed Time from the SPIRE instrument team, ESAC scientists, and a mission scientist. The HerMES data were accessed through the HeDaM data base (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://hedam.oamp.fr\" target=\"_blank\">http://hedam.oamp.fr</a>) operated by CeSAM and hosted by the Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille. This research used the facilities of the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre operated by the National Research Council of Canada with the support of the Canadian Space Agency. This work is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained from the data archive at the Space Telescope Institute. STScI is operated by the association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under the NASA contract NAS 5-26555. This work is also based (in part) on observations made with the <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em>, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology under a contract with NASA. Support for this work was provided by NASA. The Dark Cosmology Centre is funded by the Danish National Research Council.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><em>Herschel</em> is an ESA space observatory with science instruments provided by European-led Principal Investigator consortia and with important participation from NASA.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830086 id=\"91830086\" The galaxy IDs denote each galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1, and the letters indicate the multiple images of each galaxy (with <em>a</em> being the most northern images in each case and <em>c</em> being the most southern images). The position of image 4.b, as inferred from the lensing model, is obscured by foreground cluster galaxies. The amplification factors are derived from the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> modelling in Section\u00a02. The redshift of Galaxy 8 is unknown, but has similar colours to the other high-redshift multiply imaged galaxies, a disturbed morphology, and was found to be important for reproducing the SW extension of the submm arc; thus, we assume a nominal redshift of 2.9. The superscript letters on the redshifts denote the method by which they were derived: <em>a</em> for redshifts derived from the lensing model, <em>b</em> for a spectroscopic redshift, and <em>c</em> for a nominally chosen value. The reported magnitudes are AB magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Gal ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of images for the eight high-<em>z</em> galaxies, as well as one low-redshift interloper at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157. The galaxy IDs denote each galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1, and the letters indicate the multiple images of each galaxy (with <em>a</em> being the most northern images in each case and <em>c</em> being the most southern images). The position of image 4.b, as inferred from the lensing model, is obscured by foreground cluster galaxies. The amplification factors are derived from the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> modelling in Section\u00a02. The redshift of Galaxy 8 is unknown, but has similar colours to the other high-redshift multiply imaged galaxies, a disturbed morphology, and was found to be important for reproducing the SW extension of the submm arc; thus, we assume a nominal redshift of 2.9. The superscript letters on the redshifts denote the method by which they were derived: <em>a</em> for redshifts derived from the lensing model, <em>b</em> for a spectroscopic redshift, and <em>c</em> for a nominally chosen value. The reported magnitudes are AB magnitudes.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Gal ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>160<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>110<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" The total <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> for the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group is (3.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>, which gives an SFR of (450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a050) M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The 95th percentile upper limits are given for galaxies not found to be contributing to the submm arc. (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Todd P. MacKenzie, Douglas Scott, Ian Smail, Edward L. Chapin, Scott C. Chapman, A. Conley, Asantha Cooray, James S. Dunlop, D. Farrah, M. Fich, Andy G. Gibb, Wayne S. Holland, R. J. Ivison, Tim Jenness, Jean-Paul Kneib, Gaelen Marsden, Johan Richard, E. I. Robson, Ivan Valtchanov, Julie L. Wardlow,  Disentangling a group of lensed submm galaxies at <em>z</em>\u223c 2.9, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 445, Issue 1, 21 November 2014, Pages 201\u2013212, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1623\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1623</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"985464\" />\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah Eccles Health Sciences Library\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu                <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f445%2f1%2f201%2f985464\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                      <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span
