xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>5.c\u00a0</td><td>04:54:10.93\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:01:24.6\u00a0</td><td>21.97\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td>23.78\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>2.89\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>ERO-B (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6.a\u00a0</td><td>04:54:12.81\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:00:47.5\u00a0</td><td>22.62\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>24.55\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>2.86\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>ERO-C (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6.b\u00a0</td><td>04:54:12.72\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:00:59.6\u00a0</td><td>24.41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>26.60\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15\u00a0</td><td>4.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>ERO-C (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>6.c\u00a0</td><td>04:54:10.88\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:01:25.8\u00a0</td><td>22.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>24.67\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09\u00a0</td><td>2.76\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>ERO-C (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7.a\u00a0</td><td>04:54:12.95\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:00:54.8\u00a0</td><td>21.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td>22.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$33\\pm 2\\phantom{0}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>2.911\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>LBG (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7.b\u00a0</td><td>04:54:12.93\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:00:57.5\u00a0</td><td>22.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td>22.76\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$45\\pm 3\\phantom{0}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>LBG (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>7.<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\text{c}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>04:54:11.11\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:01:26.6\u00a0</td><td>23.66\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>24.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>2.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>LBG (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>8\u00a0</td><td>04:54:10.55\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:01:27.3\u00a0</td><td>22.77\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>23.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>1.73\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>2.9<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>Singly imaged\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>9\u00a0</td><td>04:54:12.85\u00a0</td><td>\u22123:01:09.1\u00a0</td><td>18.91\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01\u00a0</td><td>19.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.15719<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>Foreground galaxy\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91830034\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy 8 is not multiply imaged, but has similar colours to the rest of the multiply imaged galaxies and has a disturbed morphology. If it is at the same redshift as the interacting group, our lensing model predicts no multiple images, consistent with the observations but yielding no additional constraints on its redshift from the lensing model. However, we have found that submm emission originating from near its position is important for reproducing the morphology of the submm arc (see Section\u00a05.1), and thus we have included it in our model (see Section\u00a04).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157 and has associated Multiband Imaging Photometer (MIPS) 24\u00a0\u03bcm (not described here) and PACS emission (see Section\u00a03.2); thus, it is also included in our model as a possible source of submm emission.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is apparent that the nature of the submm arc is significantly more complicated than previously thought and is likely a combination of several of the galaxies described above. More details concerning the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> modelling will be presented in a forthcoming paper by Swinbank et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830038 id=\"91830038\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>NEW SUBMM IMAGING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830039 id=\"91830039\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>SCUBA-2</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The cluster was observed with SCUBA-2 (Holland et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) on the JCMT during commissioning, as part of \u2018Guaranteed Time\u2019 for the instrument team. A total of 12.7\u00a0h between 2010 February and 2012 February achieved an rms of 15\u00a0mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> at 450\u00a0\u03bcm using 2 arcsec pixels and 1.2\u00a0mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> at 850\u00a0\u03bcm using 4 arcsec pixels. Since the submm arc had already been observed at 850\u00a0\u03bcm using SCUBA (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), the motivations for the new observations were (1) to confirm the bright lensed structure with SCUBA-2, without the complications introduced by SCUBA's requirement to chop (Borys et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and (2) to detect the lensed structure at 450\u00a0\u03bcm, at a resolution better by about a factor of 2, with the hope of resolving the submm arc into individual sources. The data were reduced using a configuration file optimized for blank fields using the <span class=\"small-caps\">smurf</span> data reduction software for SCUBA-2 (Chapin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At 850\u00a0\u03bcm, the submm arc is detected at high signal-to-noise by SCUBA-2 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Its brightest part is elongated roughly north\u2013south, and at the southern end curves to the west, just as in the original SCUBA image. The higher resolution 450\u00a0\u03bcm data trace a largely similar structure, but at a lower relative sensitivity, with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 3 after smoothing with the beam, for the brightest portion of the lensed emission. The SCUBA-2 data are constrained by both resolution at 850\u00a0\u03bcm and sensitivity at 450\u00a0\u03bcm, and thus only limited conclusions can be obtained from these two channels alone. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the SCUBA-2 data alongside the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE and PACS images for comparison, and also it shows smoothed 850\u00a0\u03bcm contours plotted over the <em>HST</em> imaging.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830042 id=\"91830042\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>Herschel</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Confusion-limited images of MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305 using <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE (Griffin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinyard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) were taken as part of the guaranteed time programme HerMES (Oliver et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The cluster was imaged at the three SPIRE wavelengths of 250, 350, and 500\u00a0\u03bcm with full width at half-maximum (FWHM) beam sizes of 18.1, 24.9, and 36.2 arcsec, respectively (Griffin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). A total of 18.3\u00a0h of observation reached an rms of 1.5, 1.5, and 1.7\u00a0mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> at 250, 350, and 500\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively, with pixel sizes of 6, 8.3, 12 arcsec. A detailed description of the map-making procedure is given in Levenson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and the most recent updated method described in Viero et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). To ensure accurate astrometry, we have stacked on the positions of over 900 <em>Spitzer</em> MIPS 24\u00a0\u03bcm sources that overlap with the field and have corrected a 1.3 arcsec shift in RA and 0.4 arcsec shift in Dec. The uncertainty in this correction is 0.2 arcsec, calculated by bootstrapping the 24\u00a0\u03bcm source list.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two PACS (Poglitsch et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) observations taken as part of the PACS Evolutionary Probe key programme (Lutz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are also available and were processed using the \u2018multiple obsid scanMapDeepSurvey\u2019 pipeline within <span class=\"small-caps\">hipe</span> 10 (Ott\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The default units were converted from Jy\u00a0pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> to Jy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup> by multiplying by the beam area and dividing by the pixel area. The beam area for the 160\u00a0\u03bcm point spread function (PSF) was found to be 180 arcsec,<sup>2</sup> and was computed by integrating over the beam profile provided by the NASA <em>Herschel</em> Science Center. A total of 5.2\u00a0h of observation reached an rms of 2\u00a0mJy beam<sup>\u22121</sup> using 3 arcsec pixels. The FWHM at 160\u00a0\u03bcm is 11.6 arcsec. For galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a03, 70\u00a0\u03bcm PACS data are expected to be dominated by warm dust, which is not well reproduced by the simple SED model adopted in Section\u00a04, and are therefore not used in this study.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The submm arc is detected across all the available submm bands (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), but with the large number of multiply imaged galaxies (seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) that are strung along the submm arc, it is unclear which galaxies are contributing. The morphology of the submm arc seen in each image is a function of both the telescope PSFs and the SEDs of the contributing galaxies. In addition to determining which galaxies are contributing, we would also like to constrain their physical properties. With the lensing model well constrained by the <em>HST</em> observations (see Section\u00a02) and this wealth of multiwavelength data, it is clear that a comprehensive modelling approach is required.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830046 id=\"91830046\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>A FRAMEWORK FOR FITTING SEDS TO CONFUSED COUNTERPARTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Both Borys et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Berciano Alba et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) performed limited modelling of the optical and radio counterparts, respectively, in an attempt to reproduce the observed submm arc. Their approach of smoothing different plausible components with the SCUBA 850\u00a0\u03bcm beam showed that the LBG and two EROs are likely contributors, but neither could fully reproduce the observed submm arc. With new SCUBA-2 and <em>Herschel</em> observations, we are able to expand on this approach and have developed a framework for fitting SEDs to the confused optical counterparts, fully exploiting the strong gravitational lensing of this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While source plane reconstruction of multiply imaged galaxies is an effective approach for high-resolution imaging (e.g. Kochanek &amp; Narayan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Colley, Tyson &amp; Turner\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), it fails in the confused regime. Because the galaxies blend together in the submm, it is impractical to trace photons back through the lensing potential and into the source plane, since much of the photon positional information has been lost due to the large telescope beams. Instead, we use the high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging to identify candidate counterparts to the submm galaxies (SMGs) in the optical, and use their positions as priors for the origin of any submm emission. We then forward-model the galaxy SEDs through the telescope filters, and use the amplification factors derived from the lensing model for each galaxy image, to reproduce the submm arc in each wavelength channel separately. Essentially, we are fitting SEDs of galaxies directly to the data, without the need for first deblending and extracting sources or smoothing and re-binning our data to the worst resolution (a process that destroys useful information).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our method is complementary to that employed by Fu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), where they forward-model a single submm source through the gravitational lens, allowing the position to vary, to reproduce the observed morphology of their Submillimeter Array (SMA) and Very Large Array observations. With their model, they were able to show that the source of the gas and dust emission was offset from the optical counterpart. However, the gravitational lensing in this case is galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing and the observations have much higher resolution than either the SCUBA-2 or <em>Herschel</em> observations presented here. The gravitational lensing presented here is for a group of galaxies being lensed by a foreground cluster and thus the set of multiple images subtends a much larger area on the sky than galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing. The optical imaging provides positions which are more than adequate for our purposes, since, with the resolutions of SCUBA-2 and <em>Herschel</em>, any small offset of the submm emission from their optical counterparts will not have a strong effect on the morphology of the submm arc; the strongest effect of an offset would be seen in the relative amplifications of the multiple images. Our method is novel in that we reproduce the morphology of the submm emission across multiple wavelengths, while simultaneously fitting source SEDs, thus tying together the multiwavelength data. These two complementary techniques (detailed source plane reconstruction and forward-modelling SEDs at fixed source positions) could be combined in the future, given the proper observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830050 id=\"91830050\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>Model SED and image reconstruction</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The first ingredient we need is an SED model for our galaxies in the submm. For the longer wavelength channels of SCUBA-2 and <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE, the SED of a galaxy is well represented by a modified blackbody with a single temperature: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n&amp;&amp;S(\\nu ,T_{\\mathrm{d},i}, z_i, C_i) = \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;C_i\\left(\\frac{\\nu (1+z_i)}{\\nu _0}\\right)^{\\beta } (\\nu (1+z_i))^3 \\left[\\mathrm{exp}\\left(\\frac{h \\nu (1+z_i)}{k_\\mathrm{B} T_{\\mathrm{d},i}}\\right)-1\\right] ^{-1},\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>S</em> is the flux density, \u03bd is the observed frequency, \u03bd<sub>0</sub> = 1.2\u2009THz = <em>c</em>/(250\u2009\u03bcm), \u03b2 is the dust emissivity, <em>T</em><sub>d, <em>i</em></sub> is the dust temperature, <em>z</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> is the redshift, <em>C</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> is a normalization factor, and the subscript <em>i</em> denotes the galaxy. We have virtually no constraining power on the dust emissivity, primarily due to the confused nature of the data, and we therefore fix it to a nominal value of 1.5. Due to the high redshifts of our galaxies, the shorter wavelength channels of <em>Herschel</em> are dominated by hot dust and are better represented by a power law on the Wien side, i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nS(\\nu ,T_{\\mathrm{d},i}, z_i, C_i)\\propto \\nu ^{-\\alpha }, \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where the power-law amplitude and the frequency at which to switch between the power law and modified blackbody are chosen so that the transition is smooth (i.e. the two functions and their first derivative are continuous); such a model has been used by Pascale et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), for example. For the same reason that we fix the value of the dust emissivity, we fix \u03b1 to a nominal value of 2.0 as found by Casey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We then propagate the individual galaxy SEDs through each telescope bandpass filter: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\bar{S}_{b}(T_{\\mathrm{d},i}, z_i, C_i) = \\frac{\\int S(\\nu ,T_{\\mathrm{d},i}, z_i, C_i) T_b(\\nu )\\mathrm{d}\\nu }{\\int T_b(\\nu )f_b(\\nu )\\mathrm{d}\\nu }, \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\bar{S}_{b}$|</span> is the galaxy flux density averaged over channel <em>b</em>, <em>T</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>(\u03bd) is the transmission for channel <em>b</em>, and <em>f</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>(\u03bd) is a calibration parameter. For <em>Herschel</em>,\u2009 <em>f</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>(\u03bd)\u00a0=\u00a0\u03bd<sub>0</sub>/\u03bd, due to assuming a power-law SED shape for observed sources, where \u03bd<sub>0</sub> is equal to <em>c</em>/(160\u2009\u03bcm), <em>c</em>/(250\u2009\u03bcm), <em>c</em>/(350\u2009\u03bcm), and <em>c</em>/(500\u2009\u03bcm) for 160, 250, 350, and 500\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively. We assume a constant calibration factor, <em>f</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>(\u03bd)\u00a0=\u00a01, for SCUBA-2, since the bandpass filters are relatively narrow and we are firmly on the Rayleigh\u2013Jeans side of the spectrum.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Using the lensing model, the SCUBA-2 and <em>Herschel</em> images are reconstructed as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_{b}(\\boldsymbol {x})=\\sum \\limits _i \\sum \\limits _j A_{ij} \\bar{S}_{b}(T_{\\mathrm{d},i}, z_i, C_i) P_\\nu (\\boldsymbol {x}-\\boldsymbol {r}_{ij}) + B_b. \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>Here <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{b}(\\boldsymbol {x})$|</span> is the flux at position <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {x}$|</span> for frequency channel <em>b</em>, <em>A</em><sub><em>ij</em></sub> is the amplification factor for image <em>j</em> of Galaxy <em>i</em> derived from the lensing model, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$P_\\nu (\\boldsymbol {x}-\\boldsymbol {r}_{ij})$|</span> is the response function (i.e. the telescope beam), with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {r}_{ij}$|</span> denoting the position of image <em>j</em> of Galaxy <em>i</em>, and <em>B</em><sub><em>b</em></sub> is the image background.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The response functions for the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE channels are approximated as Gaussians with FWHM of 18.1, 24.9, and 36.2 arcsec at 250, 350, and 500\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively, and 11.6 arcsec at 160\u00a0\u03bcm for <em>Herschel</em> PACS. Due to the high-pass filtering of the SCUBA-2 data, we need to ensure that we have an accurate model of the effective response function; thus, we simulate 7 and 15 arcsec FWHM point sources, for the 450 and 850\u00a0\u03bcm data, respectively, within the <span class=\"small-caps\">smurf</span> data reduction software, and approximate the effective response function by fitting double Gaussians to their resulting shapes. The result for the 450\u00a0\u03bcm response function is a Gaussian with FWHM of 6.86 arcsec and an amplitude of 0.893, plus a second Gaussian with FWHM of 34.6 arcsec and amplitude of\u00a0\u22120.015. The result for the 850\u00a0\u03bcm response function is a Gaussian with FWHM of 13.9 arcsec and amplitude of 0.869, plus a second Gaussian with FWHM of 25.9 arcsec and amplitude of\u00a0\u22120.077.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830054 id=\"91830054\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>Model fitting</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The SED model adopted is non-linear and due to the confused nature of this system, we expect there to be some degeneracies between fit parameters. To obtain uncertainties for each fit parameter, determine the degeneracies between them, and efficiently explore the large parameter space required, the model is fitted to the data using an Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) Metropolis\u2013Hastings algorithm (Metropolis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1953</a>; Hastings\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1970</a>) with Gibbs sampling (Geman &amp; Geman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>). This method has become widely used in astronomy, especially for fitting cosmological parameters (Lewis &amp; Bridle\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). The method requires a likelihood function to be defined to which the model is fitted. Since the SCUBA-2 450 and 850\u00a0\u03bcm and PACS 160\u00a0\u03bcm data are limited by instrumental noise, the log\u2009-likelihood functions for these data are calculated as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n-\\log L_{b}=X_{b}+ \\sum \\limits _k\\frac{(D_{b}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})-M_{b}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})/c_b)^2}{2\\sigma _{b,k}^2}, \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where subscript <em>b</em> denotes the band, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{b}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})$|</span> are the data, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {x}_{k}$|</span> denotes the position of pixel <em>k</em> in the image, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{b,k}^2$|</span> is the instrumental noise for pixel <em>k</em>, <em>c</em><sub><em>b</em></sub> is the instrument calibration factor (with a mean value of unity), and <em>X</em><sub><em>b</em></sub> is a constant.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The log\u2009-likelihood function for the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE data is more complicated, since we are limited by extragalactic confusion noise as opposed to instrumental noise. The confusion limit in each channel is 5.8, 6.3, and 6.8\u00a0mJy at 250, 350, and 500\u00a0\u03bcm, respectively (Nguyen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This means that the residuals after subtracting the model will be (i) much larger than instrumental noise, (ii) correlated spatially with the beam, and (iii) correlated across wavelengths. This is because confusion noise is real signal generated from many faint sources that are all blending together to produce an unknown and correlated variable background. Taking confusion into account, the log\u2009-likelihood function for the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE data is therefore <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n-\\log L_{\\mathrm{SPIRE}}=X_{\\mathrm{SPIRE}}+ \\frac{1}{2}\\boldsymbol{R}^\\mathrm{T}\\boldsymbol{C}^{-1}\\boldsymbol{R}, \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{R}$|</span> is a one-dimensional list of the residuals, and contains all three channels of SPIRE data (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\boldsymbol{R}=\\lbrace D_{250}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})-M_{250}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})/c_{250}, D_{350}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})-M_{350}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})/c_{350},D_{500}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})-M_{500}(\\boldsymbol {x}_{k})/c_{500}\\rbrace$|\u2060</span>), and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{C}^{-1}$|</span> is the inverse covariance matrix for the residuals. The covariance matrix, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{C}$|\u2060</span>, is estimated using the Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey (GOODS)-North HerMES field, also observed with <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE. This is the largest blank <em>Herschel</em> field with instrumental noise similar to that of the MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305 data, and has an area of 0.1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>. To estimate the covariance matrix, we extract cut-outs from the GOODS-North field, with the same dimensions as the MS\u00a00451.6\u22120305 data, and calculate the covariance between all the pixels. We then average the covariance matrices of each set of cut-outs to obtain an estimate of the true covariance matrix, ignoring regions with standard deviations greater than twice the confusion limit in any channel to avoid regions with significantly bright sources. The total log\u2009-likelihood is then <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\log L_{\\mathrm{total}}=\\log L_{850}+\\log L_{450}+\\log L_{\\mathrm{SPIRE}}+\\log L_{160}. \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Flux calibration uncertainties, <em>c</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>, are taken into account during the fitting procedure by setting priors on <em>c</em><sub><em>b</em></sub> for each band. The flux calibrations of the 160, 450, and 850\u00a0\u03bcm data are 5, 2.5, and 5\u00a0per\u2009cent, respectively (Muller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Dempsey et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). SPIRE waveband calibrations are correlated, with a covariance matrix <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nC=\\left|\\begin{array}{ccc}0.001\\,825 &amp;\\quad 0.0016 &amp;\\quad 0.0016 \\\\\r\n 0.0016 &amp;\\quad 0.001\\,825 &amp;\\quad 0.0016 \\\\\r\n 0.0016 &amp;\\quad 0.0016 &amp;\\quad 0.001\\,825 \\end{array}\\right|, \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>where the calibration is normalized to unity (Bendo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, 4\u00a0per\u2009cent correlated uncertainty between bands plus 1.5\u00a0per\u2009cent uncorrelated between bands). The calibration uncertainties are a small effect when compared to the instrumental and confusion noise within the observations.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We set no prior on the amplitude of the modified blackbodies or each unknown image background. A hard prior, <em>T</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a010\u2009K, is motivated by the fact that neither Dale et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) nor Amblard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) found any colder <em>Herschel</em> galaxies in either the nearby or distant Universe, respectively. While we have corrected the relative pointing of <em>Herschel</em> and <em>HST</em>, we are unable to find any significant pointing shift in the JCMT due to the lower signal-to-noise in the map than what is available in the <em>Herschel</em> SPIRE observations. The nominal pointing accuracy is 1.5 arcsec, and thus we include this as a prior and marginalize over any possible pointing offset along with the image backgrounds.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the possible contributing galaxies in our model. This consists of the seven multiply imaged galaxies, one singly imaged red galaxy (Galaxy 8) with disturbed morphology, and one foreground galaxy (Galaxy 9) with associated MIPS 24\u00a0\u03bcm and PACS 160\u00a0\u03bcm emission. This brings the total to nine possible contributing galaxies. Their positions are derived from the <em>HST</em> data and their amplification factors are derived from the lensing model. The redshift of Galaxy 8 is set to a nominal value of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.9 and we report the lensed far-IR luminosity and SFR for this galaxy. Galaxy image positions, amplification factors, and redshifts are held fixed during the fitting procedure since their uncertainties are small.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">By assuming that the UV radiation of hot young stars is completely absorbed and re-radiated at longer wavelengths by intervening dust, as well as assuming an initial mass function and a starburst model, it is possible to estimate a rough conversion factor between bolometric luminosity and SFR (e.g. Lehnert &amp; Heckman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Meurer et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Kennicutt\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). Here, we convert far-IR luminosities, calculated by integrating the rest-frame SEDs from 8 to 1000\u00a0\u03bcm, to SFRs using the relation estimated by Murphy et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathrm{SFR}=1.49\\times 10^{-10}\\,\\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }\\,\\mathrm{yr}^{-1} L_{\\mathrm{FIR}}/\\mathrm{L}_{\\odot }. \r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div>When reporting the uncertainties in our SFR values for each galaxy in our model, we consider only the uncertainty in far-IR luminosity and do not include any uncertainty in this relation.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91830061 id=\"91830061\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91830062 id=\"91830062\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>A compact group of galaxies at high redshift</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All galaxies listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> are included in our model and when fitted, we can clearly identify Galaxies 2, 6, 7, 8, and 9 as the sources of submm emission generating the submm arc. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the positional arrangement of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group in the source plane with squares highlighting the galaxies responsible for generating the majority of the submm arc. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> shows the data, the best-fitting model, and the residuals after subtracting the model from the data. Also included in the figure is a decomposition of the submm arc into the unique contributions of each galaxy to the total best-fitting model. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the MCMC likelihood contours for temperature and far-IR luminosity for these five galaxies, and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> lists the results along with SFRs and upper limits for Galaxies 1, 3, 4, and 5. It is apparent in the MCMC likelihood contours that there is a strong degeneracy between the far-IR luminosities of Galaxies 6 and 7.</p>                        <a id=\"91830064\" scrollto-destination=\"91830064\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=rrtI~QhzYZGi7VRrvgcYnC~uWQJu1Kqg1zkVYk8pWJa14cFz68McKORs-jZqeYySz4WGYc5TpMc4nxC-2z6NJfdLsPbpyqbX6M5Go8y7WteZIH-o2tO236PMXVFWZCWpDQBfOOypba0udgDiSCAc~lpQQ09dU382KRfZZV33~E9Sok5ZbY0mbKfq8GN-7i78QhT1FJYhjbn4K3D9TARBvYSRY~6T1NHywkzidEEo0GZAiaHwWTNAKXU0D9OCETeBFG5SJbGcXeN20fVZbyvTwO38fPwx3b~VZPqwAz0VIUtTALmMZ4WNbBbwyRJNGzLtl1sLzo1X0Qmfz4QS7nN1Jw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Source plane arrangement of the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies. Galaxies 2 through 7 are consistent with being at this redshift. Galaxy 1 lies at a slightly higher redshift, while Galaxy 8 is assumed to be part of the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group. The galaxies found to be generating the majority of the submm arc are highlighted with red backgrounds and scale with their measured far-IR luminosity. The galaxies are spread over no more than\u00a0\u223c100\u00a0kpc in projection, with many components separated by $\\sim 10\\text{--}20$\u00a0kpc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830064/stu1623fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830064\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=xDj1226XhNQIit0QzvTIYHjGbmDq4MWDPjgTcCIHaymjsn9HeletzmmfXItG5Cu5TxlrYea2suCJtUZZ92i94Nrko5g0BEsvQazi0yThFKt6e5iqmWmEZ2PmneTfE-QqOI2mQHWujLkzSbaFgb85mW4x5JrAdy8DbsJ-9Eq2qrRekwTRh7ImIiNudK~lROFrJ0dycIURfhaU89pB9T95NKFQvXVhky5A0GqJfFN6CpY6r1HOwr~0WZjpCaw-S7weC7Jss4r-1l3sHLCRSQETyv8ODLKZts~eiRCWFxQYll0bH1As-0EY16viPY~6gxd8QD3GvF8vAmdJU0ib1SPDXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830064&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Source plane arrangement of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies. Galaxies 2 through 7 are consistent with being at this redshift. Galaxy 1 lies at a slightly higher redshift, while Galaxy 8 is assumed to be part of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group. The galaxies found to be generating the majority of the submm arc are highlighted with red backgrounds and scale with their measured far-IR luminosity. The galaxies are spread over no more than\u00a0\u223c100\u00a0kpc in projection, with many components separated by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 10\\text{--}20$|</span>\u00a0kpc.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/m_stu1623fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&amp;Signature=rrtI~QhzYZGi7VRrvgcYnC~uWQJu1Kqg1zkVYk8pWJa14cFz68McKORs-jZqeYySz4WGYc5TpMc4nxC-2z6NJfdLsPbpyqbX6M5Go8y7WteZIH-o2tO236PMXVFWZCWpDQBfOOypba0udgDiSCAc~lpQQ09dU382KRfZZV33~E9Sok5ZbY0mbKfq8GN-7i78QhT1FJYhjbn4K3D9TARBvYSRY~6T1NHywkzidEEo0GZAiaHwWTNAKXU0D9OCETeBFG5SJbGcXeN20fVZbyvTwO38fPwx3b~VZPqwAz0VIUtTALmMZ4WNbBbwyRJNGzLtl1sLzo1X0Qmfz4QS7nN1Jw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Source plane arrangement of the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies. Galaxies 2 through 7 are consistent with being at this redshift. Galaxy 1 lies at a slightly higher redshift, while Galaxy 8 is assumed to be part of the z\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group. The galaxies found to be generating the majority of the submm arc are highlighted with red backgrounds and scale with their measured far-IR luminosity. The galaxies are spread over no more than\u00a0\u223c100\u00a0kpc in projection, with many components separated by $\\sim 10\\text{--}20$\u00a0kpc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91830064/stu1623fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91830064\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/445/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1623/2/stu1623fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467569&Signature=xDj1226XhNQIit0QzvTIYHjGbmDq4MWDPjgTcCIHaymjsn9HeletzmmfXItG5Cu5TxlrYea2suCJtUZZ92i94Nrko5g0BEsvQazi0yThFKt6e5iqmWmEZ2PmneTfE-QqOI2mQHWujLkzSbaFgb85mW4x5JrAdy8DbsJ-9Eq2qrRekwTRh7ImIiNudK~lROFrJ0dycIURfhaU89pB9T95NKFQvXVhky5A0GqJfFN6CpY6r1HOwr~0WZjpCaw-S7weC7Jss4r-1l3sHLCRSQETyv8ODLKZts~eiRCWFxQYll0bH1As-0EY16viPY~6gxd8QD3GvF8vAmdJU0ib1SPDXA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91830064&ar=985464&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1623fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Source plane arrangement of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group galaxies. Galaxies 2 through 7 are consistent with being at this redshift. Galaxy 1 lies at a slightly higher redshift, while Galaxy 8 is assumed to be part of the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 group. The galaxies found to be generating the majority of the submm arc are highlighted with red backgrounds and scale with their measured far-IR luminosity. The galaxies are spread over no more than\u00a0\u223c100\u00a0kpc in projection, with many components separated by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 10\\text{--}20$|</span>\u00a0kpc.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91830065\" scrollto-destination=\"91830065\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing-amplification-corrected results from the model. The total <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> for the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group is (3.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>, which gives an SFR of (450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a050) M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The 95th percentile upper limits are given for galaxies not found to be contributing to the submm arc. Note that Galaxy 9 is a foreground galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.157 and is therefore not lensed.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Gal<span aria-hidden=\"true\"       </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing-amplification-corrected results from the model. The total <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> for the <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.9 galaxy group is (3.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>, which gives an SFR of (450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a050) M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The 95th percentile upper limits are given for galaxies not found to be contributing to the submm arc.
